annotations.1: [1-10] A hymn attributed to Hannah, the mother of Samuel, as her thanksgiving to God because she has borne a son despite her previous sterility. She praises God as the helper of the weak ( 1 Sam 2:1-2), who casts down the mighty and raises up the lowly ( 1 Sam 2:3-5), and who alone is the source of true strength ( 1 Sam 2:8-10); the hymn ends with a prayer for the king ( 1 Sam 2:10). This canticle has several points of resemblance with our Lady's Magnificat
annotations.2: [1] Horn: the symbol of strength; cf Psalm 18:3; 75:5; 89:18; 112:9.
annotations.3: [3] Speak . . . mouths: addressed to the enemies mentioned in 1 Sam 2:1
annotations.4: [18] Linen apron: called in Hebrew "ephod," but not the same as the high priest's ephod ( Exodus 28:6-14) or the ephod used in divination ( 1 Sam 2:28). Samuel wore a simple apron such as was worn by the priests ( 1 Sam 22:18), and on one occasion also by David ( 2 Sam 6:14)
annotations.5: [22] The bracketed words, which recall Exodus 38:8, are a gloss in the received text; they are lacking in the oldest Greek translation, and in a Hebrew manuscript from Qumran
annotations.6: [27-36] These verses propose the punishment of Eli from a point of view contemporary with the reform of Josiah ( 2 Kings 23:9; cf 1 Sam 2:36); they hint at the events recorded in 1 Sam 22:18-23 and 1 Kings 2:27. The older story of this divine warning is that in 1 Sam 3:11-1
annotations.7: [28] Ephod: a portable container, presumably of cloth, for the lots used in ritual consultation of God during the days of the Judges ( Judges 17:5; 18:14-15) and down into the time of David ( 1 Sam 14:3-5; 23:6-8; 30:7-8). The ephod of the high priest described in Exodus 28:6-8 becomes a garment upon which a breastpiece of decision symbolizes, but no longer serves for, such consultation. The Exodus text codifies a later form of the tradition

10.verse: and asked Saul: "Why do you listen to those who say, 'David is trying to harm you'?

11.verse: You see for yourself today that the LORD just now delivered you into my grasp in the cave. I had some thought of killing you, but I took pity on you instead. I decided, 'I will not raise a hand against my lord, for he is the LORD'S anointed and a father to me.'

12.verse: Look here at this end of your mantle which I hold. Since I cut off an end of your mantle and did not kill you, see and be convinced that I plan no harm and no rebellion. I have done you no wrong, though you are hunting me down to take my life.

13.verse: The LORD will judge between me and you, and the LORD will exact justice from you in my case. I shall not touch you.

14.verse: The old proverb says, 'From the wicked comes forth wickedness.' So I will take no action against you.

15.verse: Against whom are you on campaign, O king of Israel? Whom are you pursuing? A dead dog, or a single flea!

16.verse: The LORD will be the judge; he will decide between me and you. May he see this, and take my part, and grant me justice beyond your reach!"

17.verse: When David finished saying these things to Saul, Saul answered, "Is that your voice, my son David?" And he wept aloud.

18.verse: Saul then said to David: "You are in the right rather than I; you have treated me generously, while I have done you harm.

19.verse: Great is the generosity you showed me today, when the LORD delivered me into your grasp and you did not kill me.

20.verse: For if a man meets his enemy, does he send him away unharmed? May the LORD reward you generously for what you have done this day.

21.verse: And now, since I know that you shall surely be king and that sovereignty over Israel shall come into your possession,

22.verse: swear to me by the LORD that you will not destroy my descendants and that you will not blot out my name and family."

23.verse: David gave Saul his oath and Saul returned home, while David and his men went up to the refuge.

1.verse: There was a certain man from Rama-thaim, Elkanah by name, a Zuphite from the hill country of Ephraim. He was the son of Jeroham, son of Elihu, son of Tohu, son of Zuph, an Ephraimite.

2.verse: He had two wives, one named Hannah, the other Peninnah; Peninnah had children, but Hannah was childless.

3.verse: This man regularly went on pilgrimage from his city to worship the LORD of hosts and to sacrifice to him at Shiloh, where the two sons of Eli, Hophni and Phinehas, were ministering as priests of the LORD.

4.verse: When the day came for Elkanah to offer sacrifice, he used to give a portion each to his wife Peninnah and to all her sons and daughters,

5.verse: but a double portion to Hannah because he loved her, though the LORD had made her barren.

6.verse: Her rival, to upset her, turned it into a constant reproach to her that the LORD had left her barren.

7.verse: This went on year after year; each time they made their pilgrimage to the sanctuary of the LORD, Peninnah would approach her, and Hannah would weep and refuse to eat.

8.verse: Her husband Elkanah used to ask her: "Hannah, why do you weep, and why do you refuse to eat? Why do you grieve? Am I not more to you than ten sons?"

9.verse: Hannah rose after one such meal at Shiloh, and presented herself before the LORD; at the time, Eli the priest was sitting on a chair near the doorpost of the LORD'S temple.

10.verse: In her bitterness she prayed to the LORD, weeping copiously,

11.verse: and she made a vow, promising: "O LORD of hosts, if you look with pity on the misery of your handmaid, if you remember me and do not forget me, if you give your handmaid a male child, I will give him to the LORD for as long as he lives; neither wine nor liquor shall he drink, and no razor shall ever touch his head."

12.verse: As she remained long at prayer before the LORD, Eli watched her mouth,

13.verse: for Hannah was praying silently; though her lips were moving, her voice could not be heard. Eli, thinking her drunk,

14.verse: said to her, "How long will you make a drunken show of yourself? Sober up from your wine!"

15.verse: "It isn't that, my lord," Hannah answered. "I am an unhappy woman. I have had neither wine nor liquor; I was only pouring out my troubles to the LORD.

16.verse: Do not think your handmaid a ne'er-do-well; my prayer has been prompted by my deep sorrow and misery."

17.verse: Eli said, "Go in peace, and may the God of Israel grant you what you have asked of him."

18.verse: She replied, "Think kindly of your maidservant," and left. She went to her quarters, ate and drank with her husband, and no longer appeared downcast.

19.verse: Early the next morning they worshiped before the LORD, and then returned to their home in Ramah. When Elkanah had relations with his wife Hannah, the LORD remembered her.

20.verse: She conceived, and at the end of her term bore a son whom she called Samuel, since she had asked the LORD for him.

21.verse: The next time her husband Elkanah was going up with the rest of his household to offer the customary sacrifice to the LORD and to fulfill his vows,

22.verse: Hannah did not go, explaining to her husband, "Once the child is weaned, I will take him to appear before the LORD and to remain there forever; I will offer him as a perpetual nazirite."

23.verse: Her husband Elkanah answered her: "Do what you think best; wait until you have weaned him. Only, may the LORD bring your resolve to fulfillment!" And so she remained at home and nursed her son until she had weaned him.

24.verse: Once he was weaned, she brought him up with her, along with a three-year-old bull, an ephah of flour, and a skin of wine, and presented him at the temple of the LORD in Shiloh.

25.verse: After the boy's father had sacrificed the young bull, Hannah, his mother, approached Eli

26.verse: and said: "Pardon, my lord! As you live my lord, I am the woman who stood near you here, praying to the LORD.

27.verse: I prayed for this child, and the LORD granted my request.

28.verse: Now I, in turn, give him to the LORD; as long as he lives, he shall be dedicated to the LORD." She left him there;

annotations.2: [20] Since she had asked: this explanation would be more directly appropriate for the name Saul, which means "asked"; Samuel means "name of God.&quot
annotations.3: [24] An ephah: a little more than a bushel.

1.verse: The Philistines rallied their forces for battle at Socoh in Judah and camped between Socoh and Azekah at Ephes-dammim.

2.verse: Saul and the Israelites also gathered and camped in the Vale of the Terebinth, drawing up their battle line to meet the Philistines.

3.verse: The Philistines were stationed on one hill and the Israelites on an opposite hill, with a valley between them.

4.verse: A champion named Goliath of Gath came out from the Philistine camp; he was six and a half feet tall.

5.verse: He had a bronze helmet on his head and wore a bronze corselet of scale armor weighing five thousand shekels,

6.verse: and bronze greaves, and had a bronze scimitar slung from a baldric.

7.verse: The shaft of his javelin was like a weaver's heddle-bar, and its iron head weighed six hundred shekels. His shield-bearer went before him.

8.verse: He stood and shouted to the ranks of Israel: "Why come out in battle formation? I am a Philistine, and you are Saul's servants. Choose one of your men, and have him come down to me.

9.verse: If he beats me in combat and kills me, we will be your vassals; but if I beat him and kill him, you shall be our vassals and serve us."

10.verse: The Philistine continued: "I defy the ranks of Israel today. Give me a man and let us fight together."

11.verse: Saul and all the men of Israel, when they heard this challenge of the Philistine, were dismayed and terror-stricken.

12.verse: (David was the son of an Ephrathite named Jesse, who was from Bethlehem in Judah. He had eight sons, and in the days of Saul was old and well on in years.

13.verse: The three oldest sons of Jesse had followed Saul to war; these three sons who had gone off to war were named, the first-born Eliab, the second son Abinadab, and the third Shammah.

14.verse: David was the youngest. While the three oldest had joined Saul,

15.verse: David would go and come from Saul to tend his father's sheep at Bethlehem.

16.verse: (Meanwhile the Philistine came forward and took his stand morning and evening for forty days.

17.verse: (Now Jesse said to his son David: "Take this ephah of roasted grain and these ten loaves for your brothers, and bring them quickly to your brothers in the camp.

18.verse: Also take these ten cheeses for the field officer. Greet your brothers and bring home some token from them.

19.verse: Saul, and they, and all Israel are fighting against the Philistines in the Vale of the Terebinth."

20.verse: Early the next morning, having left the flock with a shepherd, David set out on his errand, as Jesse had commanded him. He reached the barricade of the camp just as the army, on their way to the battleground, were shouting their battle cry.

21.verse: The Israelites and the Philistines drew up opposite each other in battle array.

22.verse: David entrusted what he had brought to the keeper of the baggage and hastened to the battle line, where he greeted his brothers.

23.verse: While he was talking with them, the Philistine champion, by name Goliath of Gath, came up from the ranks of the Philistines and spoke as before, and David listened.

24.verse: When the Israelites saw the man, they all retreated before him, very much afraid.

25.verse: The Israelites had been saying: "Do you see this man coming up? He comes up to insult Israel. If anyone should kill him, the king would give him great wealth, and his daughter as well, and would grant exemption to his father's family in Israel."

26.verse: David now said to the men standing by: "What will be done for the man who kills this Philistine and frees Israel of the disgrace? Who is this uncircumcised Philistine in any case, that he should insult the armies of the living God?"

27.verse: They repeated the same words to him and said, "That is how the man who kills him will be rewarded."

28.verse: When Eliab, his oldest brother, heard him speaking with the men, he grew angry with David and said: "Why did you come down? With whom have you left those sheep in the desert meanwhile? I know your arrogance and your evil intent. You came down to enjoy the battle!"

29.verse: David replied, "What have I done now? - I was only talking."

30.verse: Yet he turned from him to another and asked the same question; and everyone gave him the same answer as before.

31.verse: The words that David had spoken were overheard and reported to Saul, who sent for him.)

32.verse: Then David spoke to Saul: "Let your majesty not lose courage. I am at your service to go and fight this Philistine."

33.verse: But Saul answered David, "You cannot go up against this Philistine and fight with him, for you are only a youth, while he has been a warrior from his youth."

34.verse: Then David told Saul: "Your servant used to tend his father's sheep, and whenever a lion or bear came to carry off a sheep from the flock,

35.verse: I would go after it and attack it and rescue the prey from its mouth. If it attacked me, I would seize it by the jaw, strike it, and kill it.

36.verse: Your servant has killed both a lion and a bear, and this uncircumcised Philistine will be as one of them, because he has insulted the armies of the living God."

37.verse: David continued: "The LORD, who delivered me from the claws of the lion and the bear, will also keep me safe from the clutches of this Philistine." Saul answered David, "Go! the LORD will be with you."

38.verse: Then Saul clothed David in his own tunic, putting a bronze helmet on his head and arming him with a coat of mail.

39.verse: David also girded himself with Saul's sword over the tunic. He walked with difficulty, however, since he had never tried armor before. He said to Saul, "I cannot go in these, because I have never tried them before." So he took them off.

40.verse: Then, staff in hand, David selected five smooth stones from the wadi and put them in the pocket of his shepherd's bag. With his sling also ready to hand, he approached the Philistine.

41.verse: With his shield-bearer marching before him, the Philistine also advanced closer and closer to David.

42.verse: When he had sized David up, and seen that he was youthful, and ruddy, and handsome in appearance, he held him in contempt.

43.verse: The Philistine said to David, "Am I a dog that you come against me with a staff?" Then the Philistine cursed David by his gods

44.verse: and said to him, "Come here to me, and I will leave your flesh for the birds of the air and the beasts of the field."

45.verse: David answered him: "You come against me with sword and spear and scimitar, but I come against you in the name of the LORD of hosts, the God of the armies of Israel that you have insulted.

46.verse: Today the LORD shall deliver you into my hand; I will strike you down and cut off your head. This very day I will leave your corpse and the corpses of the Philistine army for the birds of the air and the beasts of the field; thus the whole land shall learn that Israel has a God.

47.verse: All this multitude, too, shall learn that it is not by sword or spear that the LORD saves. For the battle is the LORD'S, and he shall deliver you into our hands."

48.verse: The Philistine then moved to meet David at close quarters, while David ran quickly toward the battle line in the direction of the Philistine.

49.verse: David put his hand into the bag and took out a stone, hurled it with the sling, and struck the Philistine on the forehead. The stone embedded itself in his brow, and he fell prostrate on the ground.

50.verse: (Thus David overcame the Philistine with sling and stone; he struck the Philistine mortally, and did it without a sword.)

51.verse: Then David ran and stood over him; with the Philistine's own sword (which he drew from its sheath) he dispatched him and cut off his head.When they saw that their hero was dead, the Philistines took to flight.

52.verse: Then the men of Israel and Judah, with loud shouts, went in pursuit of the Philistines to the approaches of Gath and to the gates of Ekron, and Philistines fell wounded along the road from Shaaraim as far as Gath and Ekron.

53.verse: On their return from the pursuit of the Philistines, the Israelites looted their camp.

54.verse: David took the head of the Philistine and brought it to Jerusalem; but he kept Goliath's armor in his own tent.

55.verse: (When Saul saw David go out to meet the Philistine, he asked his general Abner, "Abner, whose son is that youth?" Abner replied, "As truly as your majesty is alive, I have no idea."

56.verse: And the king said, "Find out whose son the lad is."

57.verse: So when David returned from slaying the Philistine, Abner took him and presented him to Saul. David was still holding the Philistine's head.

58.verse: Saul then asked him, "Whose son are you, young man?" David replied, "I am the son of your servant Jesse of Bethlehem."

annotations.1: [6] Scimitar: the Hebrew word for this is rather rare, and the nature of the weapon was in doubt until recent years. It is not the same as the sword of 1 Sam 17:45.
annotations.3: [12-31] An alternative account of how David came to undertake the combat with the Philistine is here inserted; it is continued in 1 Sam 17:55-58; 18:1-6. See note on 1 Sam 16:18
annotations.4: [54] At the time supposed by this narrative, Jerusalem was still Jebusite, and David had no military tent of his own; the verse is a later gloss

1.verse: So the inhabitants of Kiriath-jearim came for the ark of the LORD and brought it into the house of Abinadab on the hill, appointing his son Eleazar as guardian of the ark of the LORD.

2.verse: From the day the ark came to rest in Kiriath-jearim a long time-twenty years-elapsed, and the whole Israelite population turned to the LORD.

3.verse: Samuel said to them: "If you wish with your whole heart to return to the LORD, put away your foreign gods and your Ashtaroth, devote yourselves to the LORD, and worship him alone. Then he will deliver you from the power of the Philistines."

4.verse: So the Israelites put away their Baals and Ashtaroth, and worshiped the LORD alone.

5.verse: Samuel then gave orders, "Gather all Israel to Mizpah, that I may pray to the LORD for you."

6.verse: When they were gathered at Mizpah, they drew water and poured it out on the ground before the LORD, and they fasted that day, confessing, "We have sinned against the LORD." It was at Mizpah that Samuel began to judge the Israelites.

7.verse: When the Philistines heard that the Israelites had gathered at Mizpah, their lords went up against Israel. Hearing this, the Israelites became afraid of the Philistines

8.verse: and said to Samuel, "Implore the LORD our God unceasingly for us, to save us from the clutches of the Philistines."

9.verse: Samuel therefore took an unweaned lamb and offered it entire as a holocaust to the LORD. He implored the LORD for Israel, and the LORD heard him.

10.verse: While Samuel was offering the holocaust, the Philistines advanced to join battle with Israel. That day, however, the LORD thundered loudly against the Philistines, and threw them into such confusion that they were defeated by Israel.

11.verse: Thereupon the Israelites sallied forth from Mizpah and pursued the Philistines, harrying them down beyond Beth-car.

12.verse: Samuel then took a stone and placed it between Mizpah and Jeshanah; he named it Ebenezer, explaining, "To this point the LORD helped us."

13.verse: Thus were the Philistines subdued, never again to enter the territory of Israel, for the LORD was severe with them as long as Samuel lived.

14.verse: The cities from Ekron to Gath which the Philistines had taken from Israel were restored to them. Israel also freed the territory of these cities from the dominion of the Philistines. Moreover there was peace between Israel and the Amorites.

15.verse: Samuel judged Israel as long as he lived.

16.verse: He made a yearly journey, passing through Bethel, Gilgal and Mizpah and judging Israel at each of these sanctuaries.

17.verse: Then he used to return to Ramah, for that was his home. There, too, he judged Israel and built an altar to the LORD.

annotations.1: [6] Poured it out on the ground: for the symbolism, cf 2 Sam 14:4.
annotations.2: [12] Ebenezer: or eben ha-ezer, means "stone of help."

1.verse: Now the Philistines had mustered all their forces in Aphek, and the Israelites were encamped at the spring of Harod near Jezreel.

2.verse: As the Philistine lords were marching their groups of a hundred and a thousand, David and his men were marching in the rear guard with Achish.

3.verse: The Philistine chiefs asked, "What are those Hebrews doing here?" And Achish answered them: "Why, that is David, the officer of Saul, king of Israel. He has been with me now for a year or two, and I have no fault to find with him from the day he came over to me until the present."

4.verse: But the Philistine chiefs were angered at this and said to him: "Send that man back! Let him return to the place you picked out for him. He must not go down into battle with us, lest during the battle he become our enemy. For how else can he win back his master's favor, if not with the heads of these men of ours?

5.verse: Is this not the David of whom they sing during their dances, 'Saul has slain his thousands, but David his ten thousands'?"

6.verse: So Achish summoned David and said to him: "As the LORD lives, you are honest, and I should be pleased to have you active with me in the camp, for I have found nothing wrong with you from the day of your arrival to this day. But you are not welcome to the lords.

7.verse: Withdraw peaceably, now, and do nothing that might displease the Philistine lords."

8.verse: But David said to Achish: "What have I done? Or what have you against your servant from the first day I have been with you to this day, that I cannot go to fight against the enemies of my lord the king?"

9.verse: "You know," Achish answered David, "that you are acceptable to me. But the Philistine chiefs have determined you are not to go up with us to battle.

10.verse: So the first thing tomorrow, you and your lord's servants who came with you, go to the place I picked out for you. Do not decide to take umbrage at this; you are as acceptable to me as an angel of God. But make an early morning start, as soon as it grows light, and be on your way."

11.verse: So David and his men left early in the morning to return to the land of the Philistines. The Philistines, however, went on up to Jezreel.

1.verse: Samuel died, and all Israel gathered to mourn him; they buried him at his home in Ramah.Then David went down to the desert of Maon.

2.verse: There was a man of Maon who had property in Carmel; he was very wealthy, owning three thousand sheep and a thousand goats. At this time he was present for the shearing of his flock in Carmel.

3.verse: The man was named Nabal, his wife, Abigail. The woman was intelligent and attractive, but Nabal himself, a Calebite, was harsh and ungenerous in his behavior.

4.verse: When David heard in the desert that Nabal was shearing his flock,

5.verse: he sent ten young men, instructing them: "Go up to Carmel. Pay Nabal a visit and greet him in my name.

6.verse: Say to him, 'Peace be with you, my brother, and with your family, and with all who belong to you.

7.verse: I have just heard that shearers are with you. Now, when your shepherds were with us, we did them no injury, neither did they miss anything all the while they were in Carmel.

8.verse: Ask your servants and they will tell you so. Look kindly on these young men, since we come at a festival time. Please give your servants and your son David whatever you can manage.'"

9.verse: When David's young men arrived, they delivered this message fully to Nabal in David's name, and then waited.

10.verse: But Nabal answered the servants of David: "Who is David? Who is the son of Jesse? Nowadays there are many servants who run away from their masters.

11.verse: Must I take my bread, my wine, my meat that I have slaughtered for my own shearers, and give them to men who come from I know not where?"

12.verse: So David's young men retraced their steps and on their return reported to him all that had been said.

13.verse: Thereupon David said to his men, "Let everyone gird on his sword." And so everyone, David included, girded on his sword. About four hundred men went up after David, while two hundred remained with the baggage.

14.verse: But Nabal's wife Abigail was informed of this by one of the servants, who said: "David sent messengers from the desert to greet our master, but he flew at them screaming.

15.verse: Yet these men were very good to us. We were done no injury, neither did we miss anything all the while we were living among them during our stay in the open country.

16.verse: For us they were like a rampart night and day the whole time we were pasturing the sheep near them.

17.verse: Now, see what you can do, for you must realize that otherwise evil is in store for our master and for his whole family. He is so mean that no one can talk to him."

18.verse: Abigail quickly got together two hundred loaves, two skins of wine, five dressed sheep, five seahs of roasted grain, a hundred cakes of pressed raisins, and two hundred cakes of pressed figs, and loaded them on asses.

19.verse: She then said to her servants, "Go on ahead; I will follow you." But she did not tell her husband Nabal.

20.verse: As she came down through a mountain defile riding on an ass, David and his men were also coming down from the opposite direction. When she met them,

21.verse: David had just been saying: "Indeed, it was in vain that I guarded all this man's possessions in the desert, so that he missed nothing. He has repaid good with evil.

22.verse: May God do thus and so to David, if by morning I leave a single male alive among all those who belong to him."

23.verse: As soon as Abigail saw David, she dismounted quickly from the ass and, falling prostrate on the ground before David, did him homage.

24.verse: As she fell at his feet she said: "My lord, let the blame be mine. Please let your handmaid speak to you, and listen to the words of your handmaid.

25.verse: Let not my lord pay attention to that worthless man Nabal, for he is just like his name. Fool is his name, and he acts the fool. I, your handmaid, did not see the young men whom my lord sent.

26.verse: Now, therefore, my lord, as the LORD lives, and as you live, it is the LORD who has kept you from shedding blood and from avenging yourself personally. May your enemies and those who seek to harm my lord become as Nabal!

27.verse: Accept this present, then, which your maidservant has brought for my lord, and let it be given to the young men who follow my lord.

28.verse: Please forgive the transgression of your handmaid, for the LORD shall certainly establish a lasting dynasty for my lord, because your lordship is fighting the battles of the LORD, and there is no evil to be found in you your whole life long.

29.verse: If anyone rises to pursue you and to seek your life, may the life of my lord be bound in the bundle of the living in the care of the LORD your God; but may he hurl out the lives of your enemies as from the hollow of a sling.

30.verse: And when the LORD carries out for my lord the promise of success he has made concerning you, and appoints you as commander over Israel,

31.verse: you shall not have this as a qualm or burden on your conscience, my lord, for having shed innocent blood or for having avenged yourself personally. When the LORD confers this benefit on your lordship, remember your handmaid."

32.verse: David said to Abigail: "Blessed be the LORD, the God of Israel, who sent you to meet me today.

33.verse: Blessed be your good judgment and blessed be you yourself, who this day have prevented me from shedding blood and from avenging myself personally.

34.verse: Otherwise, as the LORD, the God of Israel, lives, who has restrained me from harming you, if you had not come so promptly to meet me, by dawn Nabal would not have had a single man or boy left alive."

35.verse: David then took from her what she had brought him and said to her: "Go up to your home in peace! See, I have granted your request as a personal favor."

36.verse: When Abigail came to Nabal, there was a drinking party in his house like that of a king, and Nabal was merry because he was very drunk. So she told him nothing at all before daybreak the next morning.

37.verse: But then, when Nabal had become sober, his wife told him what had happened. At this his courage died within him, and he became like a stone.

38.verse: About ten days later the LORD struck him and he died.

39.verse: On hearing that Nabal was dead, David said: "Blessed be the LORD, who has requited the insult I received at the hand of Nabal, and who restrained his servant from doing evil, but has punished Nabal for his own evil deeds." David then sent a proposal of marriage to Abigail.

40.verse: When David's servants came to Abigail in Carmel, they said to her, "David has sent us to you that he may take you as his wife."

41.verse: Rising and bowing to the ground, she answered, "Your handmaid would become a slave to wash the feet of my lord's servants."

42.verse: She got up immediately, mounted an ass, and followed David's messengers, with her five maids following in attendance upon her. She became his wife,

43.verse: and David also married Ahinoam of Jezreel. Thus both of them were his wives; but Saul gave David's wife Michal, Saul's own daughter, to Palti, son of Laish, who was from Gallim.

annotations.1: [25] Fool is his name: Nabal in Hebrew means "a fool."
annotations.2: [26] Abigail anticipates that some misfortune will shortly overtake Nabal, as in fact it does ( 1 Sam 25:37-38)
annotations.3: [29] The bundle of the living: the figure is perhaps taken from the practice of tying up valuables in a kerchief or bag for safekeeping. Abigail desires that David enjoy permanent peace and security, but that his enemies be subject to constant agitation and humiliation like a stone whirled about, cast out of the sling, and thereafter disregarded.

1.verse: Before David and his men reached Ziklag on the third day, the Amalekites had raided the Negeb and Ziklag, had stormed the city, and had set it on fire.

2.verse: They had taken captive the women and all who were in the city, young and old, killing no one; they had carried them off when they left.

3.verse: David and his men arrived at the city to find it burned to the ground and their wives, sons and daughters taken captive.

4.verse: Then David and those who were with him wept aloud until they could weep no more.

5.verse: David's two wives, Ahinoam of Jezreel and Abigail, the widow of Nabal from Carmel, had also been carried off with the rest.

6.verse: Now David found himself in great difficulty, for the men spoke of stoning him, so bitter were they over the fate of their sons and daughters. But with renewed trust in the LORD his God,

7.verse: David said to Abiathar, the priest, son of Ahimelech, "Bring me the ephod!" When Abiathar brought him the ephod,

8.verse: David inquired of the LORD, "Shall I pursue these raiders? Can I overtake them?" The LORD answered him, "Go in pursuit, for you shall surely overtake them and effect a rescue."

9.verse: So David went off with his six hundred men and came as far as the Wadi Besor, where those who were to remain behind halted.

10.verse: David continued the pursuit with four hundred men, but two hundred were too exhausted to cross the Wadi Besor and remained behind.

11.verse: An Egyptian was found in the open country and brought to David. He was provided with food, which he ate, and given water to drink;

12.verse: a cake of pressed figs and two cakes of pressed raisins were also offered to him. When he had eaten, he revived; he had not taken food nor drunk water for three days and three nights.

13.verse: Then David asked him, "To whom do you belong, and where do you come from?" He replied: "I am an Egyptian, the slave of an Amalekite. My master abandoned me because I fell sick three days ago today.

14.verse: We raided the Negeb of the Cherethites, the territory of Judah, and the Negeb of Caleb; and we set Ziklag on fire."

15.verse: David then asked him, "Will you lead me down to this raiding party?" He answered, "Swear to me by God that you will not kill me or deliver me to my master, and I will lead you to the raiding party."

16.verse: He did lead them, and there were the Amalekites scattered all over the ground, eating, drinking, and in a festive mood because of all the rich booty they had taken from the land of the Philistines and from the land of Judah.

17.verse: From dawn to sundown David attacked them, putting them under the ban so that none escaped except four hundred young men, who mounted their camels and fled.

18.verse: David recovered everything the Amalekites had taken, and rescued his two wives.

19.verse: Nothing was missing, small or great, booty or sons or daughters, of all that the Amalekites had taken. David brought back everything.

20.verse: Moreover, David took all the sheep and oxen, and as they drove these before him, they shouted, "This is David's spoil!"

21.verse: When David came to the two hundred men who had been too exhausted to follow him, and whom he had left behind at the Wadi Besor, they came out to meet David and the men with him. On nearing them David greeted them.

22.verse: But all the stingy and worthless men among those who had accompanied David spoke up to say, "Since they did not accompany us, we will not give them anything from the booty, except to each man his wife and children. Let them take those along and be on their way."

23.verse: But David said: "You must not do this, my brothers, after what the LORD has given us. He has protected us and delivered into our grip the band that came against us.

24.verse: Who could agree with this proposal of yours? Rather, the share of the one who goes down to battle and that of the one who remains with the baggage shall be the same; they shall share alike."

25.verse: And from that day forward he made it a law and a custom in Israel, as it still is today.

26.verse: When David came to Ziklag, he sent part of the spoil to the elders of Judah, city by city, saying, "This is a gift to you from the spoil of the enemies of the LORD":

27.verse: to those in Bethel, to those in Ramoth-negeb, to those in Jattir,

28.verse: to those in Aroer, to those in Siphmoth, to those in Eshtemoa,

29.verse: to those in Racal, to those in the Jerahmeelite cities, to those in the Kenite cities,

30.verse: to those in Hormah, to those in Borashan, to those in Athach,

31.verse: to those in Hebron, and to all the places frequented by David and his men.

1.verse: During the time young Samuel was minister to the LORD under Eli, a revelation of the LORD was uncommon and vision infrequent.

2.verse: One day Eli was asleep in his usual place. His eyes had lately grown so weak that he could not see.

3.verse: The lamp of God was not yet extinguished, and Samuel was sleeping in the temple of the LORD where the ark of God was.

4.verse: The LORD called to Samuel, who answered, "Here I am."

5.verse: He ran to Eli and said, "Here I am. You called me." "I did not call you," Eli said. "Go back to sleep." So he went back to sleep.

6.verse: Again the LORD called Samuel, who rose and went to Eli. "Here I am," he said. "You called me." But he answered, "I did not call you, my son. Go back to sleep."

7.verse: At that time Samuel was not familiar with the LORD, because the LORD had not revealed anything to him as yet.

8.verse: The LORD called Samuel again, for the third time. Getting up and going to Eli, he said, "Here I am. You called me." Then Eli understood that the LORD was calling the youth.

9.verse: So he said to Samuel, "Go to sleep, and if you are called, reply, 'Speak, LORD, for your servant is listening.'" When Samuel went to sleep in his place,

10.verse: the LORD came and revealed his presence, calling out as before, "Samuel, Samuel!" Samuel answered, "Speak, for your servant is listening."

11.verse: The LORD said to Samuel: "I am about to do something in Israel that will cause the ears of everyone who hears it to ring.

12.verse: On that day I will carry out in full against Eli everything I threatened against his family.

13.verse: I announce to him that I am condemning his family once and for all, because of this crime: though he knew his sons were blaspheming God, he did not reprove them.

14.verse: Therefore, I swear to the family of Eli that no sacrifice or offering will ever expiate its crime."

15.verse: Samuel then slept until morning, when he got up early and opened the doors of the temple of the LORD. He feared to tell Eli the vision,

16.verse: but Eli called to him, "Samuel, my son!" He replied, "Here I am."

17.verse: Then Eli asked, "What did he say to you? Hide nothing from me! May God do thus and so to you if you hide a single thing he told you."

18.verse: So Samuel told him everything, and held nothing back. Eli answered, "He is the LORD. He will do what he judges best."

19.verse: Samuel grew up, and the LORD was with him, not permitting any word of his to be without effect.

20.verse: Thus all Israel from Dan to Beer-sheba came to know that Samuel was an accredited prophet of the LORD.

21.verse: The LORD continued to appear at Shiloh; he manifested himself to Samuel at Shiloh through his word,

11.verse: When all who had known him previously saw him in a prophetic state among the prophets, they said to one another, "What has happened to the son of Kish? Is Saul also among the prophets?"

13.verse: When he came out of the prophetic state, he went home.

14.verse: Saul's uncle inquired of him and his servant, "Where have you been?" Saul replied, "To look for the asses. When we could not find them, we went to Samuel."

17.verse: Samuel called the people together to the LORD at Mizpah

18.verse: and addressed the Israelites: "Thus says the LORD, the God of Israel, 'It was I who brought Israel up from Egypt and delivered you from the power of the Egyptians and from the power of all the kingdoms that oppressed you.'

20.verse: So Samuel had all the tribes of Israel come forward, and the tribe of Benjamin was chosen.

21.verse: Next he had the tribe of Benjamin come forward in clans, and the clan of Matri was chosen, and finally Saul, son of Kish, was chosen. But they looked for him in vain.

22.verse: Again they consulted the LORD, "Has he come here?" The LORD answered, "He is hiding among the baggage."

23.verse: They ran to bring him from there; and when he stood among the people, he was head and shoulders above all the crowd.

24.verse: Samuel said to all the people, "Do you see the man whom the LORD has chosen? There is none like him among all the people!" Then all the people shouted, "Long live the king!"

25.verse: Samuel next explained to the people the law of royalty and wrote it in a book, which he placed in the presence of the LORD. This done, Samuel dismissed the people, each to his own place.

26.verse: Saul also went home to Gibeah, accompanied by warriors whose hearts the LORD had touched.

27.verse: But certain worthless men said, "How can this fellow save us?" They despised him and brought him no present.

2.verse: The Philistines then drew up in battle formation against Israel. After a fierce struggle Israel was defeated by the Philistines, who slew about four thousand men on the battlefield.

3.verse: When the troops retired to the camp, the elders of Israel said, "Why has the LORD permitted us to be defeated today by the Philistines? Let us fetch the ark of the LORD from Shiloh that it may go into battle among us and save us from the grasp of our enemies."

4.verse: So the people sent to Shiloh and brought from there the ark of the LORD of hosts, who is enthroned upon the cherubim. The two sons of Eli, Hophni and Phinehas, were with the ark of God.

5.verse: When the ark of the LORD arrived in the camp, all Israel shouted so loudly that the earth resounded.

6.verse: The Philistines, hearing the noise of shouting, asked, "What can this loud shouting in the camp of the Hebrews mean?" On learning that the ark of the LORD had come into the camp,

7.verse: the Philistines were frightened. They said, "Gods have come to their camp." They said also, "Woe to us! This has never happened before.

8.verse: Woe to us! Who can deliver us from the power of these mighty gods? These are the gods that struck the Egyptians with various plagues and with pestilence.

9.verse: Take courage and be manly, Philistines; otherwise you will become slaves to the Hebrews, as they were your slaves. So fight manfully!"

10.verse: The Philistines fought and Israel was defeated; every man fled to his own tent. It was a disastrous defeat, in which Israel lost thirty thousand foot soldiers.

11.verse: The ark of God was captured, and Eli's two sons, Hophni and Phinehas, were among the dead.

12.verse: A Benjaminite fled from the battlefield and reached Shiloh that same day, with his clothes torn and his head covered with dirt.

13.verse: When he arrived, Eli was sitting in his chair beside the gate, watching the road, for he was troubled at heart about the ark of God. The man, however, went into the city to divulge his news, which put the whole city in an uproar.

14.verse: Hearing the outcry of the men standing near him, Eli inquired, "What does this commotion mean?"

15.verse: (Eli was ninety-eight years old, and his eyes would not focus, so that he could not see.)

16.verse: The man quickly came up to Eli and said, "It is I who have come from the battlefield; I fled from there today." He asked, "What happened, my son?"

17.verse: And the messenger answered: "Israel fled from the Philistines; in fact, the troops suffered heavy losses. Your two sons, Hophni and Phinehas, are among the dead, and the ark of God has been captured."

18.verse: At this mention of the ark of God, Eli fell backward from his chair into the gateway; since he was an old man and heavy, he died of a broken neck. He had judged Israel for forty years.

19.verse: His daughter-in-law, the wife of Phinehas, was with child and at the point of giving birth. When she heard the news concerning the capture of the ark and the deaths of her father-in-law and her husband, she was seized with the pangs of labor, and gave birth.

20.verse: She was about to die when the women standing around her said to her, "Never fear! You have given birth to a son." Yet she neither answered nor paid any attention.

21.verse: (She named the child Ichabod, saying, "Gone is the glory from Israel," with reference to the capture of the ark of God and to her father-in-law and her husband.)

1.verse: David fled from the sheds near Ramah, and went to Jonathan. "What have I done?" he asked him. "What crime or what offense does your father hold against me that he seeks my life?"

2.verse: Jonathan answered him: "Heaven forbid that you should die! My father does nothing, great or small, without disclosing it to me. Why, then, should my father conceal this from me? This cannot be so!"

3.verse: But David replied: "Your father is well aware that I am favored with your friendship, so he has decided, 'Jonathan must not know of this lest he be grieved.' Nevertheless, as the LORD lives and as you live, there is but a step between me and death."

4.verse: Jonathan then said to David, "I will do whatever you wish."

5.verse: David answered: "Tomorrow is the new moon, when I should in fact dine with the king. Let me go and hide in the open country until evening.

6.verse: If it turns out that your father misses me, say, 'David urged me to let him go on short notice to his city Bethlehem, because his whole clan is holding its seasonal sacrifice there.'

7.verse: If he says, 'Very well,' your servant is safe. But if he becomes quite angry, you can be sure he has planned some harm.

9.verse: But Jonathan answered: "Not I! If ever I find out that my father is determined to inflict injury upon you, I will certainly let you know."

10.verse: David then asked Jonathan, "Who will tell me if your father gives you a harsh answer?"

11.verse: (Jonathan replied to David, "Come, let us go out into the field." When they were out in the open country together,

13.verse: Should it please my father to bring any injury upon you, may the LORD do thus and so to Jonathan if I do not apprise you of it and send you on your way in peace. May the LORD be with you even as he was with my father.

21.verse: I will then send my attendant to go and recover the arrows. If in fact I say to him, 'Look, the arrow is this side of you; pick it up,' come, for you are safe. As the LORD lives, there will be nothing to fear.

32.verse: But Jonathan asked his father Saul: "Why should he die? What has he done?"

38.verse: Again he called to his lad, "Hurry, be quick, don't delay!" Jonathan's boy picked up the arrow and brought it to his master.

40.verse: Then Jonathan gave his weapons to this boy of his and said to him, "Go, take them to the city."

1.verse: There was a stalwart man from Benjamin named Kish, who was the son of Abiel, son of Zeror, son of Becorath, son of Aphiah, a Benjaminite.

2.verse: He had a son named Saul, who was a handsome young man. There was no other Israelite handsomer than Saul; he stood head and shoulders above the people.

3.verse: Now the asses of Saul's father, Kish, had wandered off. Kish said to his son Saul, "Take one of the servants with you and go out and hunt for the asses."

4.verse: Accordingly they went through the hill country of Ephraim, and through the land of Shalishah. Not finding them there, they continued through the land of Shaalim without success. They also went through the land of Benjamin, but they failed to find the animals.

5.verse: When they came to the land of Zuph, Saul said to the servant who was with him, "Come, let us turn back, lest my father forget about the asses and become anxious about us."

6.verse: The servant replied, "Listen! There is a man of God in this city, a man held in high esteem; all that he says is sure to come true. Let us go there now! Perhaps he can tell us how to accomplish our errand."

7.verse: But Saul said to his servant, "If we go, what can we offer the man? There is no bread in our bags, and we have no present to give the man of God. What have we?"

8.verse: Again the servant answered Saul, "I have a quarter of a silver shekel. If I give that to the man of God, he will tell us our way."

9.verse: (In former times in Israel, anyone who went to consult God used to say, "Come, let us go to the seer." For he who is now called prophet was formerly called seer.)

10.verse: Saul then said to his servant, "Well said! Come on, let us go!" And they went to the city where the man of God lived.

11.verse: As they were going up the ascent to the city, they met some girls coming out to draw water and inquired of them, "Is the seer in town?"

12.verse: The girls answered, "Yes, there - straight ahead. Hurry now; just today he came to the city, because the people have a sacrifice today on the high place.

13.verse: When you enter the city, you may reach him before he goes up to the high place to eat. The people will not eat until he arrives; only after he blesses the sacrifice will the invited guests eat. Go up immediately, for you should find him right now."

14.verse: So they went up to the city. As they entered it, Samuel was coming toward them on his way to the high place.

15.verse: The day before Saul's arrival, the LORD had given Samuel the revelation:

16.verse: "At this time tomorrow I will send you a man from the land of Benjamin whom you are to anoint as commander of my people Israel. He shall save my people from the clutches of the Philistines, for I have witnessed their misery and accepted their cry for help."

17.verse: When Samuel caught sight of Saul, the LORD assured him, "This is the man of whom I told you; he is to govern my people."

18.verse: Saul met Samuel in the gateway and said, "Please tell me where the seer lives."

19.verse: Samuel answered Saul: "I am the seer. Go up ahead of me to the high place and eat with me today. In the morning, before dismissing you, I will tell you whatever you wish.

20.verse: As for the asses you lost three days ago, do not worry about them, for they have been found. Whom does Israel desire ardently if not you and your father's family?"

21.verse: Saul replied: "Am I not a Benjaminite, of one of the smallest tribes of Israel, and is not my clan the least among the clans of the tribe of Benjamin? Why say such things to me?"

22.verse: Samuel then took Saul and his servant and brought them to the room, where he placed them at the head of the guests, of whom there were about thirty.

23.verse: He said to the cook, "Bring the portion I gave you and told you to put aside."

24.verse: So the cook took up the leg and what went with it, and placed it before Saul. Samuel said: "This is a reserved portion that has been set before you. Eat, for it was kept for you until your arrival; I explained that I was inviting some guests." Thus Saul dined with Samuel that day.

25.verse: When they came down from the high place into the city, a mattress was spread for Saul on the roof,

26.verse: and he slept there. At daybreak Samuel called to Saul on the roof, "Get up, and I will start you on your journey." Saul rose, and he and Samuel went outside the city together.

27.verse: As they were approaching the edge of the town, Samuel said to Saul, "Tell the servant to go on ahead of us, but stay here yourself for the moment, that I may give you a message from God."
