annotations.4: [24] And what went with it: a slight change would give "and the fatty tail" as perhaps the original reading. Sheep in the Near East are exceptionally fat-tailed, and such a portion would be thought a special delicacy by the Hebrews. However, the ritual legislation as we know it ( Lev 3:9) would require that the fat tail be burned on the altar. If this general rule was later than the time of Samuel, the present text may have been retouched so as not to seem to contravene it. A Qumran text has "the festive (leg)" here.

1.verse: Men from Ziph came to Saul in Gibeah, reporting that David was hiding on the hill of Hachilah at the edge of the wasteland.

2.verse: So Saul went off down to the desert of Ziph with three thousand picked men of Israel, to search for David in the desert of Ziph.

3.verse: Saul camped beside the road on the hill of Hachilah, at the edge of the wasteland. David, who was living in the desert, saw that Saul had come into the desert after him

4.verse: and sent out scouts, who confirmed Saul's arrival.

5.verse: David himself then went to the place where Saul was encamped and examined the spot where Saul and Abner, son of Ner, the general, had their sleeping quarters. Saul's were within the barricade, and all his soldiers were camped around him.

6.verse: David asked Ahimelech the Hittite, and Abishai, son of Zeruiah and brother of Joab, "Who will go down into the camp with me to Saul?" Abishai replied, "I will."

7.verse: So David and Abishai went among Saul's soldiers by night and found Saul lying asleep within the barricade, with his spear thrust into the ground at his head and Abner and his men sleeping around him.

8.verse: Abishai whispered to David: "God has delivered your enemy into your grasp this day. Let me nail him to the ground with one thrust of the spear; I will not need a second thrust!"

9.verse: But David said to Abishai, "Do not harm him, for who can lay hands on the LORD'S anointed and remain unpunished?

10.verse: As the LORD lives," David continued, "it must be the LORD himself who will strike him, whether the time comes for him to die, or he goes out and perishes in battle.

11.verse: But the LORD forbid that I touch his anointed! Now take the spear which is at his head and the water jug, and let us be on our way."

12.verse: So David took the spear and the water jug from their place at Saul's head, and they got away without anyone's seeing or knowing or awakening. All remained asleep, because the LORD had put them into a deep slumber.

13.verse: Going across to an opposite slope, David stood on a remote hilltop at a great distance from Abner, son of Ner, and the troops.

14.verse: He then shouted, "Will you not answer, Abner?" And Abner answered, "Who is it that calls me?"

15.verse: David said to Abner: "Are you not a man whose like does not exist in Israel? Why, then, have you not guarded your lord the king when one of his subjects went to kill the king, your lord?

16.verse: This is no creditable service you have performed. As the LORD lives, you people deserve death because you have not guarded your lord, the LORD'S anointed. Go, look: where are the king's spear and the water jug that was at his head?"

17.verse: Saul recognized David's voice and asked, "Is that your voice, my son David?" David answered, "Yes, my lord the king."

18.verse: He continued: "Why does my lord pursue his servant? What have I done? What evil do I plan?

19.verse: Please, now, let my lord the king listen to the words of his servant. If the LORD has incited you against me, let an offering appease him; but if men, may they be cursed before the LORD, because they have exiled me so that this day I have no share in the LORD'S inheritance, but am told: 'Go serve other gods!'

20.verse: Do not let my blood flow to the ground far from the presence of the LORD. For the king of Israel has come out to seek a single flea as if he were hunting partridge in the mountains."

21.verse: Then Saul said: "I have done wrong. Come back, my son David, I will not harm you again, because you have held my life precious today. Indeed, I have been a fool and have made a serious mistake."

22.verse: But David answered: "Here is the king's spear. Let an attendant come over to get it.

23.verse: The LORD will reward each man for his justice and faithfulness. Today, though the LORD delivered you into my grasp, I would not harm the LORD'S anointed.

24.verse: As I valued your life highly today, so may the LORD value my life highly and deliver me from all difficulties."

25.verse: Then Saul said to David: "Blessed are you, my son David! You shall certainly succeed in whatever you undertake." David went his way, and Saul returned to his home.

annotations.1: [19] The Lord's inheritance: the land of Israel ( Deut 32:8-9) under the Lord's special protection, where he could be freely worshiped.

1.verse: David received information that the Philistines were attacking Keilah and plundering the threshing floors.

2.verse: So he consulted the LORD, inquiring, "Shall I go and defeat these Philistines?" The LORD answered, "Go, for you will defeat the Philistines and rescue Keilah."

3.verse: But David's men said to him: "We are afraid here in Judah. How much more so if we go to Keilah against the forces of the Philistines!"

4.verse: Again David consulted the LORD, who answered, "Go down to Keilah, for I will deliver the Philistines into your power."

5.verse: David then went with his men to Keilah and fought with the Philistines. He drove off their cattle and inflicted a severe defeat on them, and thus rescued the inhabitants of Keilah.

6.verse: Abiathar, son of Ahimelech, who had fled to David, went down with David to Keilah, taking the ephod with him.

7.verse: When Saul was told that David had entered Keilah, he said: "God has put him in my grip. Now he has shut himself in, for he has entered a city with gates and bars."

8.verse: Saul then called all the people to war, in order to go down to Keilah and besiege David and his men.

9.verse: When David found out that Saul was planning to harm him, he said to the priest Abiathar, "Bring forward the ephod."

10.verse: David then said: "O LORD God of Israel, your servant has heard a report that Saul plans to come to Keilah, to destroy the city on my account.

11.verse: Will they hand me over? And now: will Saul come down as your servant has heard? O LORD God of Israel, tell your servant." The LORD answered, "He will come down."

12.verse: David then asked, "Will the citizens of Keilah deliver me and my men into the grasp of Saul?" And the LORD answered, "Yes."

13.verse: So David and his men, about six hundred in number, left Keilah and wandered from place to place. When Saul was informed that David had escaped from Keilah, he abandoned the expedition.

14.verse: David now lived in the refuges in the desert, or in the barren hill country near Ziph. Though Saul sought him continually, the LORD did not deliver David into his grasp.

15.verse: David was apprehensive because Saul had come out to seek his life; but while he was at Horesh in the barrens near Ziph,

16.verse: Saul's son, Jonathan, came down there to David and strengthened his resolve in the LORD.

17.verse: He said to him: "Have no fear, my father Saul shall not lay a hand to you. You shall be king of Israel and I shall be second to you. Even my father Saul knows this."

18.verse: They made a joint agreement before the LORD in Horesh, where David remained, while Jonathan returned to his home.

19.verse: Some of the Ziphites went up to Saul in Gibeah and said, "David is hiding among us, now in the refuges, and again at Horesh, or on the hill of Hachilah, south of the wasteland.

20.verse: Therefore, whenever the king wishes to come down, let him do so. It will be our task to deliver him into the king's grasp."

21.verse: Saul replied: "The LORD bless you for your sympathy toward me.

22.verse: Go now and make sure once more! Take note of the place where he sets foot" (for he thought, perhaps they are playing some trick on me).

23.verse: "Look around and learn in which of all the various hiding places he is holding out. Then come back to me with sure information, and I will go with you. If he is in the region, I will search him out among all the families of Judah."

24.verse: So they went off to Ziph ahead of Saul. At this time David and his men were in the desert below Maon, in the Arabah south of the wasteland.

25.verse: When Saul and his men came looking for him, David got word of it and went down to the gorge in the desert below Maon. Saul heard of this and pursued David into the desert below Maon.

26.verse: As Saul moved along one rim of the gorge, David and his men took to the other. David was in anxious flight to escape Saul, and Saul and his men were attempting to outflank David and his men in order to capture them,

27.verse: when a messenger came to Saul, saying, "Come quickly, because the Philistines have invaded the land."

28.verse: Saul interrupted his pursuit of David and went to meet the Philistines. This is how that place came to be called the Gorge of Divisions.

1.verse: The Philistines, having captured the ark of God, transferred it from Ebenezer to Ashdod.

2.verse: They then took the ark of God and brought it into the temple of Dagon, placing it beside Dagon.

3.verse: When the people of Ashdod rose early the next morning, Dagon was lying prone on the ground before the ark of the LORD. So they picked Dagon up and replaced him.

4.verse: But the next morning early, when they arose, Dagon lay prone on the ground before the ark of the LORD, his head and hands broken off and lying on the threshold, his trunk alone intact.

5.verse: For this reason, neither the priests of Dagon nor any others who enter the temple of Dagon tread on the threshold of Dagon in Ashdod to this very day; they always step over it.

6.verse: Now the LORD dealt severely with the people of Ashdod. He ravaged and afflicted the city and its vicinity with hemorrhoids; he brought upon the city a great and deadly plague of mice that swarmed in their ships and overran their fields.

7.verse: On seeing how matters stood, the men of Ashdod decided, "The ark of the God of Israel must not remain with us, for he is handling us and our god Dagon severely."

8.verse: So they summoned all the Philistine lords and inquired of them, "What shall we do with the ark of the God of Israel?" The men of Gath replied, "Let them move the ark of the God of Israel on to us."

9.verse: So they moved the ark of the God of Israel to Gath! But after it had been brought there, the LORD threw the city into utter turmoil: he afflicted its inhabitants, young and old, and hemorrhoids broke out on them.

10.verse: The ark of God was next sent to Ekron; but as it entered that city, the people there cried out, "Why have they brought the ark of the God of Israel here to kill us and our kindred?"

11.verse: Then they, too, sent a summons to all the Philistine lords and pleaded: "Send away the ark of the God of Israel. Let it return to its own place, that it may not kill us and our kindred." A deadly panic had seized the whole city, since the hand of God had been very heavy upon it.

12.verse: Those who escaped death were afflicted with hemorrhoids, and the outcry from the city went up to the heavens.

annotations.1: [6] Hemorrhoids . . . mice: a double calamity fell upon them - a plague of mice or rats, and a severe epidemic of pestilential tumors, probably the bubonic plague.

1.verse: One day Jonathan, son of Saul, said to his armor-bearer, "Come let us go over to the Philistine outpost on the other side." But he did not inform his father.

2.verse: (Saul's command post was under the pomegranate tree near the threshing floor on the outskirts of Geba; those with him numbered about six hundred men.

3.verse: Ahijah, son of Ahitub, brother of Ichabod, who was the son of Phinehas, son of Eli, the priest of the LORD at Shiloh, was wearing the ephod.) Nor did the soldiers know that Jonathan had gone.

4.verse: Flanking the ravine through which Jonathan intended to get over to the Philistine outpost there was a rocky crag on each side, one called Bozez, the other Seneh.

5.verse: One crag was to the north, toward Michmash, the other to the south, toward Geba.

6.verse: Jonathan said to his armor-bearer: "Come let us go over to that outpost of the uncircumcised. Perhaps the LORD will help us, because it is no more difficult for the LORD to grant victory through a few than through many."

7.verse: His armor-bearer replied, "Do whatever you are inclined to do; I will match your resolve."

8.verse: Jonathan continued: "We shall go over to those men and show ourselves to them.

9.verse: If they say to us, 'Stay there until we can come to you,' we shall stop where we are; we shall not go up to them.

10.verse: But if they say, 'Come up to us,' we shall go up, because the LORD has delivered them into our grasp. That will be our sign."

11.verse: Accordingly, the two of them appeared before the outpost of the Philistines, who said, "Look, some Hebrews are coming out of the holes where they have been hiding."

12.verse: The men of the outpost called to Jonathan and his armor-bearer. "Come up here," they said, "and we will teach you a lesson." So Jonathan said to his armor-bearer, "Climb up after me, for the LORD has delivered them into the grasp of Israel."

13.verse: Jonathan clambered up with his armor-bearer behind him; as the Philistines turned to flee him, he cut them down, and his armor-bearer followed him and finished them off.

14.verse: In this first exploit Jonathan and his armor-bearer slew about twenty men within half a furlong.

15.verse: Then panic spread to the army and to the countryside, and all the soldiers, including the outpost and the raiding parties, were terror-stricken. The earth also shook, so that the panic was beyond human endurance.

16.verse: The lookouts of Saul in Geba of Benjamin saw that the enemy camp had scattered and were running about in all directions.

17.verse: Saul said to those around him, "Count the troops and find out if any of us are missing." When they had investigated, they found Jonathan and his armor-bearer missing.

18.verse: Saul then said to Ahijah, "Bring the ephod here." (Ahijah was wearing the ephod in front of the Israelites at that time.)

19.verse: While Saul was speaking to the priest, the tumult in the Philistine camp kept increasing. So he said to the priest, "Withdraw your hand."

20.verse: And Saul and all his men shouted and rushed into the fight, where the Philistines, wholly confused, were thrusting swords at one another.

21.verse: In addition, the Hebrews who had previously sided with the Philistines and had gone up with them to the camp, turned to join the Israelites under Saul and Jonathan.

22.verse: Likewise, all the Israelites who were hiding in the hill country of Ephraim, on hearing that the Philistines were fleeing, pursued them in the rout.

23.verse: Thus the LORD saved Israel that day. The battle continued past Beth-horon;

24.verse: the whole people, about ten thousand combatants, were with Saul, and there was scattered fighting in every town in the hill country of Ephraim. And Saul swore a very rash oath that day, putting the people under this ban: "Cursed be the man who takes food before evening, before I am able to avenge myself on my enemies." So none of the people tasted food.

25.verse: Indeed, there was a honeycomb lying on the ground,

26.verse: and when the soldiers came to the comb the swarm had left it; yet no one would raise a hand to his mouth from it, because the people feared the oath.

27.verse: Jonathan, who had not heard that his father had put the people under oath, thrust out the end of the staff he was holding and dipped in into the honey. Then he raised it to his mouth and his eyes lit up.

28.verse: At this one of the soldiers spoke up: "Your father put the people under a strict oath, saying, 'Cursed be the man who takes food this day!' As a result the people are weak."

29.verse: Jonathan replied: "My father brings trouble to the land. Look how bright my eyes are from this small taste of honey I have had.

30.verse: What is more, if the people had eaten freely today of their enemy's booty when they came across it, would not the slaughter of the Philistines by now have been the greater for it?"

31.verse: After the Philistines were routed that day from Michmash to Aijalon, the people were completely exhausted.

32.verse: So they pounced upon the spoil and took sheep, oxen and calves, slaughtering them on the ground and eating the flesh with blood.

33.verse: Informed that the people were sinning against the LORD by eating the flesh with blood, Saul said: "You have broken faith. Roll a large stone here for me."

34.verse: He continued: "Mingle with the people and tell each of them to bring his ox or his sheep to me. Slaughter it here and then eat, but you must not sin against the LORD by eating the flesh with blood." So everyone brought to the LORD whatever ox he had seized, and they slaughtered them there;

35.verse: and Saul built an altar to the LORD - this was the first time he built an altar to the LORD.

36.verse: Then Saul said, "Let us go down in pursuit of the Philistines by night, to plunder among them until daybreak and to kill them all off." They replied, "Do what you think best." But the priest said, "Let us consult God."

37.verse: So Saul inquired of God: "Shall I go down in pursuit of the Philistines? Will you deliver them into the power of Israel?" But he received no answer on this occasion.

38.verse: Saul then said, "Come here, all officers of the army. We must investigate and find out how this sin was committed today.

39.verse: As the LORD lives who has given victory to Israel, even if my son Jonathan has committed it, he shall surely die!" But none of the people answered him.

40.verse: So he said to all Israel, "Stand on one side, and I and my son Jonathan will stand on the other." The people responded, "Do what you think best."

41.verse: And Saul said to the LORD, the God of Israel: "Why did you not answer your servant this time? If the blame for this resides in me or my son Jonathan, LORD, God of Israel, respond with Urim; but if this guilt is in your people Israel, respond with Thummim." Jonathan and Saul were designated, and the people went free.

42.verse: Saul then said, "Cast lots between me and my son Jonathan." And Jonathan was designated.

43.verse: Saul said to Jonathan, "Tell me what you have done." Jonathan replied, "I only tasted a little honey from the end of the staff I was holding. Am I to die for this?"

44.verse: Saul said, "May God do thus and so to me if you do not indeed die, Jonathan!"

45.verse: But the army said to Saul: "Is Jonathan to die, though it was he who brought Israel this great victory? This must not be! As the LORD lives, not a single hair of his head shall fall to the ground, for God was with him in what he did today!" Thus the soldiers were able to rescue Jonathan from death.

46.verse: After that Saul gave up the pursuit of the Philistines, who returned to their own territory.

47.verse: After taking over the kingship of Israel, Saul waged war on all their surrounding enemies - Moab, the Ammonites, Aram, Beth-rehob, the king of Zobah, and the Philistines. Wherever he turned, he was successful

48.verse: and fought bravely. He defeated Amalek and delivered Israel from the hands of those who were plundering them.

49.verse: The sons of Saul were Jonathan, Ishvi, and Malchishua; his two daughters were named, the elder, Merob, and the younger, Michal.

50.verse: Saul's wife, who was named Ahinoam, was the daughter of Ahimaaz. The name of his general was Abner, son of Saul's uncle, Ner;

51.verse: Kish, Saul's father, and Ner, Abner's father, were sons of Abiel.

52.verse: An unremitting war was waged against the Philistines during Saul's lifetime. When Saul saw any strong or brave man, he took him into his service.

annotations.1: [18] Ephod: to be used in consulting God; see note on 1 Sam 14:41; 2:28
annotations.2: [23] Past Beth-horon: this is a textual correction influenced by 1 Sam 13:18; the received Hebrew text refers to Bethel (Beth-aven), but the effect of the victory would seem to have been that the main ridge of mountains in the territories of Benjamin and Ephraim was cleared of Philistines
annotations.3: [41] The Urim and Thummim, or sacred lots, were a device for ascertaining the will of God; they ceased to be used after the time of David. The material and the shape of these objects, and the manner in which they were used, are unknown. They gave a "yes" or "no" answer to specific questions
annotations.4: [45] Rescue: the Hebrew word used is that for the "redemption" of the first-born ( Exodus 13:13-15)
annotations.5: [49] Ishvi: known also as Ishbaal, in 2 Sam 2:8 and elsewhere. The name may once have read "Ishyo" here

1.verse: About a month later, Nahash the Ammonite went up and laid siege to Jabesh-gilead. All the men of Jabesh begged Nahash, "Make a treaty with us, and we will be your subjects."

2.verse: But Nahash the Ammonite replied, "This is my condition for a treaty with you: I must gouge out every man's right eye, that I may thus bring ignominy on all Israel."

3.verse: The elders of Jabesh said to him: "Give us seven days to send messengers throughout the territory of Israel. If no one rescues us, we will surrender to you."

4.verse: When the messengers arrived at Gibeah of Saul, they related the news to the people, all of whom wept aloud.

5.verse: Just then Saul came in from the field, behind his oxen. "Why are the people weeping?" he asked. The message of the inhabitants of Jabesh was repeated to him.

6.verse: As he listened to this report, the spirit of God rushed upon him and he became very angry.

7.verse: Taking a yoke of oxen, he cut them into pieces, which he sent throughout the territory of Israel by couriers with the message, "If anyone does not come out to follow Saul (and Samuel), the same as this will be done to his oxen!" In dread of the LORD, the people turned out to a man.

8.verse: When he reviewed them in Bezek, there were three hundred thousand Israelites and seventy thousand Judahites.

9.verse: To the messengers who had come he said, "Tell the inhabitants of Jabeshgilead that tomorrow, while the sun is hot, they will be rescued." The messengers came and reported this to the inhabitants of Jabesh, who were jubilant,

10.verse: and said to Nahash, "Tomorrow we will surrender to you, and you may do whatever you please with us."

11.verse: On the appointed day, Saul arranged his troops in three companies and invaded the camp during the dawn watch. They slaughtered Ammonites until the heat of the day; by then the survivors were so scattered that no two were left together.

12.verse: The people then said to Samuel: "Who questioned whether Saul should rule over us? Hand over the men and we will put them to death."

13.verse: But Saul broke in to say, "No man is to be put to death this day, for today the LORD has saved Israel."

14.verse: Samuel said to the people, "Come, let us go to Gilgal to inaugurate the kingdom there."

15.verse: So all the people went to Gilgal, where, in the presence of the LORD, they made Saul king. They also sacrificed peace offerings there before the LORD, and Saul and all the Israelites celebrated the occasion with great joy.

annotations.1: [1] About a month later: there is ancient evidence for a longer introduction to this campaign. The time indication here may refer to its earlier stages rather than to the events of 1 Sam 10.
annotations.2: [12-14] With these verses, an editor has harmonized the account of the acknowledgment of Saul as king at Mizpah ( 1 Sam 10:17-24) with the public acclamation at Gilgal ( 1 Sam 11:15) after the defeat of the Ammonites ( 1 Sam 11:1-11). The Greek text of 1 Sam 11:15 reads "and Samuel anointed Saul as king," instead of they made Saul king.

1.verse: But David said to himself: "I shall perish some day at the hand of Saul. I have no choice but to escape to the land of the Philistines; then Saul will give up his continual search for me throughout the land of Israel, and I shall be out of his reach."

2.verse: Accordingly, David departed with his six hundred men and went over to Achish, son of Maoch, king of Gath.

3.verse: David and his men lived in Gath with Achish; each one had his family, and David had his two wives, Ahinoam from Jezreel and Abigail, the widow of Nabal from Carmel.

4.verse: When Saul was told that David had fled to Gath, he no longer searched for him.

5.verse: David said to Achish: "If I meet with your approval, let me have a place to live in one of the country towns. Why should your servant live with you in the royal city?"

6.verse: That same day Achish gave him Ziklag, which has, therefore, belonged to the kings of Judah up to the present time.

7.verse: In all, David lived a year and four months in the country of the Philistines.

8.verse: David and his men went up and made raids on the Geshurites, Girzites, and Amalekites-peoples living in the land between Telam, on the approach to Shur, and the land of Egypt.

9.verse: In attacking the land David would not leave a man or woman alive, but would carry off sheep, oxen, asses, camels, and clothes. On his return he brought these to Achish,

10.verse: who asked, "Whom did you raid this time?" And David answered, "The Negeb of Judah," or "The Negeb of Jerahmeel," or "The Negeb of the Kenites."

11.verse: But David would not leave a man or woman alive to be brought to Gath, fearing that they would betray him by saying, "This is what David did." This was his custom as long as he lived in the country of the Philistines.

12.verse: And Achish trusted David, thinking, "He must certainly be detested by his people Israel. I shall have him as my vassal forever."

annotations.1: [6] Has . . . belonged to the kings of Judah: as a personal holding, outside the system of tribal lands; Jerusalem, when taken by David, had a similar status ( 2 Sam 5:7-9).

1.verse: The LORD said to Samuel: "How long will you grieve for Saul, whom I have rejected as king of Israel? Fill your horn with oil, and be on your way. I am sending you to Jesse of Bethlehem, for I have chosen my king from among his sons."

2.verse: But Samuel replied: "How can I go? Saul will hear of it and kill me." To this the LORD answered: "Take a heifer along and say, 'I have come to sacrifice to the LORD.'

3.verse: Invite Jesse to the sacrifice, and I myself will tell you what to do; you are to anoint for me the one I point out to you."

4.verse: Samuel did as the LORD had commanded him. When he entered Bethlehem, the elders of the city came trembling to meet him and inquired, "Is your visit peaceful, O seer?"

5.verse: He replied: "Yes! I have come to sacrifice to the LORD. So cleanse yourselves and join me today for the banquet." He also had Jesse and his sons cleanse themselves and invited them to the sacrifice.

6.verse: As they came, he looked at Eliab and thought, "Surely the LORD'S anointed is here before him."

7.verse: But the LORD said to Samuel: "Do not judge from his appearance or from his lofty stature, because I have rejected him. Not as man sees does God see, because man sees the appearance but the LORD looks into the heart."

8.verse: Then Jesse called Abinadab and presented him before Samuel, who said, "The Lord has not chosen him."

9.verse: Next Jesse presented Shammah, but Samuel said, "The LORD has not chosen this one either."

10.verse: In the same way Jesse presented seven sons before Samuel, but Samuel said to Jesse, "The LORD has not chosen any one of these."

11.verse: Then Samuel asked Jesse, "Are these all the sons you have?" Jesse replied, "There is still the youngest, who is tending the sheep." Samuel said to Jesse, "Send for him; we will not begin the sacrificial banquet until he arrives here."

12.verse: Jesse sent and had the young man brought to them. He was ruddy, a youth handsome to behold and making a splendid appearance. The LORD said, "There-anoint him, for this is he!"

13.verse: Then Samuel, with the horn of oil in hand, anointed him in the midst of his brothers; and from that day on, the spirit of the LORD rushed upon David. When Samuel took his leave, he went to Ramah.

14.verse: The spirit of the LORD had departed from Saul, and he was tormented by an evil spirit sent by the LORD.

15.verse: So the servants of Saul said to him: "Please! An evil spirit from God is tormenting you.

16.verse: If your lordship will order it, we, your servants here in attendance on you, will look for a man skilled in playing the harp. When the evil spirit from God comes over you, he will play and you will feel better."

17.verse: Saul then told his servants, "Find me a skillful harpist and bring him to me."

18.verse: A servant spoke up to say: "I have observed that one of the sons of Jesse of Bethlehem is a skillful harpist. He is also a stalwart soldier, besides being an able speaker, and handsome. Moreover, the LORD is with him."

19.verse: Accordingly, Saul dispatched messengers to ask Jesse to send him his son David, who was with the flock.

20.verse: Then Jesse took five loaves of bread, a skin of wine, and a kid, and sent them to Saul by his son David.

21.verse: Thus David came to Saul and entered his service. Saul became very fond of him, made him his armor-bearer,

22.verse: and sent Jesse the message, "Allow David to remain in my service, for he meets with my approval."

23.verse: Whenever the spirit from God seized Saul, David would take the harp and play, and Saul would be relieved and feel better, for the evil spirit would leave him.

annotations.1: [1] The anointing here prepared for is unknown to David's brother Eliab in the next chapter ( 1 Sam 17:28), and David is twice anointed after Saul's death ( 2 Sam 2:4; 5:3).
annotations.2: [14] An evil spirit sent by the LORD: the Lord permitted Saul to be tormented with violent fits of rage
annotations.3: [18] Of the two traditions which describe the coming of David into Saul's service, the oldest Greek translation retains only the one comprised in 1 Sam 16:14-23; 17:1-11, 32-54. This effort at consistency is not in accord with the character of the rest of the book; see note on 1 Sam 8:1. Though square brackets are used in this edition to indicate the passages lacking in the oldest translation, this is meant only to help the reader follow one account at a time. 1.verse: Saul discussed his intention of killing David with his son Jonathan and with all his servants. But Saul's son Jonathan, who was very fond of David,

2.verse: told him: "My father Saul is trying to kill you. Therefore, please be on your guard tomorrow morning; get out of sight and remain in hiding.

3.verse: I, however, will go out and stand beside my father in the countryside where you are, and will speak to him about you. If I learn anything, I will let you know."

4.verse: Jonathan then spoke well of David to his father Saul, saying to him: "Let not your majesty sin against his servant David, for he has committed no offense against you, but has helped you very much by his deeds.

5.verse: When he took his life in his hands and slew the Philistine, and the LORD brought about a great victory for all Israel through him, you were glad to see it. Why, then, should you become guilty of shedding innocent blood by killing David without cause?"

6.verse: Saul heeded Jonathan's plea and swore, "As the LORD lives, he shall not be killed."

7.verse: So Jonathan summoned David and repeated the whole conversation to him. Jonathan then brought David to Saul, and David served him as before.

8.verse: When war broke out again, David went out to fight against the Philistines and inflicted a great defeat upon them, putting them to flight.

9.verse: Then an evil spirit from the LORD came upon Saul as he was sitting in his house with spear in hand and David was playing the harp nearby.

10.verse: Saul tried to nail David to the wall with the spear, but David eluded Saul, so that the spear struck only the wall, and David got away safe.

11.verse: The same night, Saul sent messengers to David's house to guard it, that he might kill him in the morning. David's wife Michal informed him, "Unless you save yourself tonight, tomorrow you will be killed."

12.verse: Then Michal let David down through a window, and he made his escape in safety.

13.verse: Michal took the household idol and laid it in the bed, putting a net of goat's hair at its head and covering it with a spread.

14.verse: When Saul sent messengers to arrest David, she said, "He is sick."

15.verse: Saul, however, sent the messengers back to see David and commanded them, "Bring him up to me in the bed, that I may kill him."

16.verse: But when the messengers entered, they found the household idol in the bed, with the net of goat's hair at its head.

17.verse: Saul therefore asked Michal: "Why did you play this trick on me? You have helped my enemy to get away!" Michal answered Saul: "He threatened me, 'Let me go or I will kill you.'"

18.verse: Thus David got safely away; he went to Samuel in Ramah, informing him of all that Saul had done to him. Then he and Samuel went to stay in the sheds.

19.verse: When Saul was told that David was in the sheds near Ramah,

20.verse: he sent messengers to arrest David. But when they saw the band of prophets, presided over by Samuel, in a prophetic frenzy, they too fell into the prophetic state.

21.verse: Informed of this, Saul sent other messengers, who also fell into the prophetic state. For the third time Saul sent messengers, but they too fell into the prophetic state.

22.verse: Saul then went to Ramah himself. Arriving at the cistern of the threshing floor on the bare hilltop, he inquired, "Where are Samuel and David?", and was told, "At the sheds near Ramah."

23.verse: As he set out from the hilltop toward the sheds, the spirit of God came upon him also, and he continued on in a prophetic condition until he reached the spot. At the sheds near Ramah

24.verse: he, too, stripped himself of his garments and he, too, remained in the prophetic state in the presence of Samuel; all that day and night he lay naked. That is why they say, "Is Saul also among the prophets?"

3.verse: Now Samuel had died and, after being mourned by all Israel, was buried in his city, Ramah. Meanwhile Saul had driven mediums and fortune-tellers out of the land.

4.verse: The Philistine levies advanced to Shunem and encamped. Saul, too, mustered all Israel; they camped on Gilboa.

5.verse: When Saul saw the camp of the Philistines, he was dismayed and lost heart completely.

6.verse: He therefore consulted the LORD; but the LORD gave no answer, whether in dreams or by the Urim or through prophets.

7.verse: Then Saul said to his servants, "Find me a woman who is a medium, to whom I can go to seek counsel through her." His servants answered him, "There is a woman in Endor who is a medium."

8.verse: So he disguised himself, putting on other clothes, and set out with two companions. They came to the woman by night, and Saul said to her, "Tell my fortune through a ghost; conjure up for me the one I ask you to."

9.verse: But the woman answered him, "You are surely aware of what Saul has done, in driving the mediums and fortune-tellers out of the land. Why, then, are you laying snares for my life, to have me killed?"

10.verse: But Saul swore to her by the LORD, "As the LORD lives, you shall incur no blame for this."

11.verse: Then the woman asked him, "Whom do you want me to conjure up?" and he answered, "Samuel."

12.verse: When the woman saw Samuel, she shrieked at the top of her voice and said to Saul, "Why have you deceived me? You are Saul!"

13.verse: But the king said to her, "Have no fear. What do you see?" The woman answered Saul, "I see a preternatural being rising from the earth."

14.verse: "What does he look like?" asked Saul. And she replied, "It is an old man who is rising, clothed in a mantle." Saul knew that it was Samuel, and so he bowed face to the ground in homage.

15.verse: Samuel then said to Saul, "Why do you disturb me by conjuring me up?" Saul replied: "I am in great straits, for the Philistines are waging war against me and God has abandoned me. Since he no longer answers me through prophets or in dreams, I have called you to tell me what I should do."

16.verse: To this Samuel said: "But why do you ask me, if the LORD has abandoned you and is with your neighbor?

17.verse: The LORD has done to you what he foretold through me: he has torn the kingdom from your grasp and has given it to your neighbor David.

18.verse: "Because you disobeyed the LORD'S directive and would not carry out his fierce anger against Amalek, the LORD has done this to you today.

19.verse: Moreover, the LORD will deliver Israel, and you as well, into the clutches of the Philistines. By tomorrow you and your sons will be with me, and the LORD will have delivered the army of Israel into the hands of the Philistines."

20.verse: Immediately Saul fell full length on the ground, for he was badly shaken by Samuel's message. Moreover, he had no bodily strength left, since he had eaten nothing all that day and night.

21.verse: Then the woman came to Saul, and seeing that he was quite terror-stricken, said to him: "Remember, your maidservant obeyed you: I took my life in my hands and fulfilled the request you made of me.

22.verse: Now you, in turn, please listen to your maidservant. Let me set something before you to eat, so that you may have strength when you go on your way."

23.verse: But he refused, saying, "I will not eat." However, when his servants joined the woman in urging him, he listened to their entreaties, got up from the ground, and sat on a couch.

24.verse: The woman had a stall-fed calf in the house, which she now quickly slaughtered. Then taking flour, she kneaded it and baked unleavened bread.

25.verse: She set the meal before Saul and his servants, and they ate. Then they stood up and left the same night.

annotations.1: [1] From this chapter on, the First Book of Samuel gives us two and sometimes three viewpoints on most of the events with which it is concerned, such as the appointment of Saul as king, the reasons for his downfall, his relationship with David, even the circumstances of Saul's death (1 Sam 31; 2 Sam 1). The choice of Saul as king is seen, in 1 Sam 8, followed by 1 Sam 10:17-27 and 1 Sam 12 as motivated by the people's defection from the proper service of God; this later editorial approach incorporates not only narratives with which it is consistent, but also early traditions ( 1 Sam 9:1-10, 16 and 1 Sam 11) which portray the events and their motivation quite differently.

1.verse: Samuel said to Saul: "It was I the LORD sent to anoint you king over his people Israel. Now, therefore, listen to the message of the LORD.

2.verse: This is what the LORD of hosts has to say: 'I will punish what Amalek did to Israel when he barred his way as he was coming up from Egypt.

3.verse: Go, now, attack Amalek, and deal with him and all that he has under the ban. Do not spare him, but kill men and women, children and infants, oxen and sheep, camels and asses.'"

4.verse: Saul alerted the soldiers, and at Telaim reviewed two hundred thousand foot soldiers and ten thousand men of Judah.

5.verse: Saul went to the city of Amalek, and after setting an ambush in the wadi,

6.verse: warned the Kenites: "Come! Leave Amalek and withdraw, that I may not have to destroy you with them, for you were kind to the Israelites when they came up from Egypt." After the Kenites left,

7.verse: Saul routed Amalek from Havilah to the approaches of Shur, on the frontier of Egypt.

8.verse: He took Agag, king of Amalek, alive, but on the rest of the people he put into effect the ban of destruction by the sword.

9.verse: He and his troops spared Agag and the best of the fat sheep and oxen, and the lambs. They refused to carry out the doom on anything that was worthwhile, dooming only what was worthless and of no account.

10.verse: Then the LORD spoke to Samuel:

11.verse: "I regret having made Saul king, for he has turned from me and has not kept my command." At this Samuel grew angry and cried out to the LORD all night.

12.verse: Early in the morning he went to meet Saul, but was informed that Saul had gone to Carmel, where he erected a trophy in his own honor, and that on his return he had passed on and gone down to Gilgal.

13.verse: When Samuel came to him, Saul greeted him: "The LORD bless you! I have kept the command of the LORD."

14.verse: But Samuel asked, "What, then, is the meaning of this bleating of sheep that comes to my ears, and the lowing of oxen that I hear?"

15.verse: Saul replied: "They were brought from Amalek. The men spared the best sheep and oxen to sacrifice to the LORD, your God; but we have carried out the ban on the rest."

16.verse: Samuel said to Saul: "Stop! Let me tell you what the LORD said to me last night." "Speak!" he replied.

17.verse: Samuel then said: "Though little in your own esteem, are you not leader of the tribes of Israel? The LORD anointed you king of Israel

18.verse: and sent you on a mission, saying, 'Go and put the sinful Amalekites under a ban of destruction. Fight against them until you have exterminated them.'

19.verse: Why then have you disobeyed the LORD? You have pounced on the spoil, thus displeasing the LORD."

20.verse: Saul answered Samuel: "I did indeed obey the LORD and fulfill the mission on which the LORD sent me. I have brought back Agag, and I have destroyed Amalek under the ban.

21.verse: But from the spoil the men took sheep and oxen, the best of what had been banned, to sacrifice to the LORD their God in Gilgal."

24.verse: Saul replied to Samuel: "I have sinned, for I have disobeyed the command of the LORD and your instructions. In my fear of the people, I did what they said.

25.verse: Now forgive my sin, and return with me, that I may worship the LORD."

26.verse: But Samuel said to Saul, "I will not return with you, because you rejected the command of the LORD and the LORD rejects you as king of Israel."

27.verse: As Samuel turned to go, Saul seized a loose end of his mantle, and it tore off.

29.verse: The Glory of Israel neither retracts nor repents, for he is not man that he should repent."

33.verse: And Samuel said, "As your sword has made women childless, so shall your mother be childless among women." Then he cut Agag down before the LORD in Gilgal.

34.verse: Samuel departed for Ramah, while Saul went up to his home in Gibeah of Saul.
